newsitem.title: CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: Bangui army dissidents start to rejoin units.
newsitem.headline: Bangui army dissidents start to rejoin units.

text.p: Army dissidents in the Central African Republic capital Bangui began rejoining their units on Thursday under a peace deal brokered by Mali's former military leader Amadou Toumani Toure, witnesses said.

The return of the dissidents, involved in a week of bloody clashes with African peacekeepers in June, sets a January peace deal back on track. That deal was designed to end three army mutinies in under a year.
Supporters and opponents of President Ange-Felix Patasse attended a reconciliation ceremony on Wednesday.
The return of the dissidents and their weapons began from Petevo suburb, a southern stronghold of the dissidents, and from Camp Kassai, their stronghold in the east. Peacekeepers accompanied them.

The mutinies began over pay and conditions but turned into a bid to topple Patasse, a northern civilian elected in 1993. They degenerated in ethnic killings. Most mutineers were from the Yakoma tribe of former military leader Andre Kolingba.
The Red Cross says at least 100 people died in the June clashes and an estimated 60,000 civilians fled the capital. Some have since returned home.
Under the latest deal Toumani Toure and Jean-Marc Simon, the ambassador of France, the former colonial power, undertook to guarantee the dissidents' security.
France intervened in January under a defence pact to halt fighting and then handed over to the peacekeepers.
